skill.name: ghe-claim
skill.description:
CLAIM a specific GitHub issue to START working on it. Requires an issue number. Performs validation, atomic claim, posts claim comment, and sets up worktree.

USE THIS SKILL WHEN:
- User says "claim issue #N" or "claim #N"
- User says "start working on issue #N" or "take issue #N"
- User says "I'll work on #N" or "pick up #N"
- User wants to BEGIN work on a specific issue number
- User selected an issue from available work and wants to claim it

REQUIRED: An issue number must be specified or identifiable from context.

DO NOT USE THIS SKILL WHEN:
- User just wants to SEE status (use ghe-status)
- User is ALREADY working and wants to post update (use ghe-checkpoint)
- User wants to CHANGE phases (use ghe-transition)
- User wants reports (use ghe-report)
- No specific issue number is mentioned

EXAMPLES:
<example>
Context: User wants to start work on a specific issue
user: "Claim issue #201"
assistant: "I'll use ghe-claim to claim issue #201 with the full protocol"
</example>
<example>
Context: User picks from available work
user: "I'll take issue #205"
assistant: "I'll use ghe-claim to claim issue #205"
</example>
<example>
Context: User wants to start on specific feature
user: "Start working on #312"
assistant: "I'll use ghe-claim to claim and set up issue #312"
</example>

security_audit.summary: Static scanner flagged markdown documentation patterns as security issues. All findings are false positives. The skill contains no executable code, only documentation about GitHub issue management workflow. Backticks in markdown format examples were misinterpreted as shell command execution. Settings file references (~/.claude) are standard configuration locations, not malicious file access. No actual cryptographic algorithms, network calls, or code execution patterns exist in this skill file.

medium_findings.title: Markdown Code Formatting Misidentified as Shell Commands
medium_findings.description: Scanner detected backtick syntax at SKILL.md lines 73-90, 121-123, 149 as 'Ruby/shell backtick execution'. These are markdown inline code formatting examples (e.g., timestamp format `YYYYMMDDHHMMSSTimezone`, skill reference `ghe-checkpoint`). No actual command execution exists.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Inline code formatting in markdown documentation is not shell execution. No process spawning, no command execution, no user input passed to shell.

low_findings.title: Settings File Reference Misidentified as Hidden File Access
low_findings.description: Scanner flagged ~/.claude reference at SKILL.md:60 as hidden file access. This is standard configuration location for Claude Code plugins, documented as allowed boundary for settings.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Documentation explicitly lists ~/.claude as an allowed write location for plugin settings. This is standard practice, not malicious file system access.

content.user_title: Claim GitHub issues to start work
content.value_statement: GitHub issue management requires manual tracking of assignments and workflow state. This skill automates the claim process with validation, atomic assignment, and worktree setup for immediate development.
actual_capabilities: Validates issue readiness before claim (phase-gate check)
Atomically assigns issue to prevent conflicts
Posts claim comment with session header to issue thread
Creates git worktree for development phase
Updates SERENA memory bank with claim event
limitations: Requires existing GHE plugin infrastructure (not standalone)
Issue number must be explicitly provided or identifiable
Worktree creation only applies to DEV phase issues

use_cases.title: Start working on a new issue
use_cases.description: Claim issue #201 to begin development. The skill validates the issue is ready, assigns it to you, adds in-progress labels, and sets up a git worktree.

use_cases.title: Pick up available work from issue board
use_cases.description: Claim an issue from the ready column. The skill checks phase order, prevents duplicate worktrees for epics, and syncs with memory bank.

use_cases.title: Transition between phases
use_cases.description: Claim a TEST or REVIEW phase issue after DEV completion. The skill spawns appropriate thread manager and maintains phase-gate compliance.

output: Claim comment posted to issue thread
Phase check: DEV phase is complete

best_practices: Provide the full issue number with hash symbol for clarity
Mention the issue title or feature context for better tracking
Use ghe-status first to verify issue exists and check its state
Combine with ghe-transition when moving between phases
anti_patterns: Claiming issues without checking readiness status
Claiming multiple issues simultaneously (atomic claim prevents this)
Skipping phase-gate validation by manually assigning issues

faq.question: What happens if I try to claim an issue that is already assigned?
faq.answer: The phase-gate validation will fail and block the claim. The skill checks that issues have no current assignee before proceeding.

faq.question: Does claim create a git worktree for TEST or REVIEW phases?
faq.answer: No, worktree creation only occurs for DEV phase issues. TEST and REVIEW phases skip this step.

faq.question: Can I claim an issue without the 'ready' label?
faq.answer: No, the phase-gate validation requires the 'ready' label. This ensures only approved work enters the workflow.

faq.question: What is the memory bank sync for?
faq.answer: It updates the SERENA activeContext.md file to track all active work, enabling session continuity across Claude restarts.

faq.question: How does atomic claim prevent conflicts?
faq.answer: The claim operation is atomic at the GitHub API level - if two agents try to claim simultaneously, one will receive an assignment conflict error.

faq.question: What if the SERENA sync setting is disabled?
faq.answer: The skill will skip the memory bank update step and still complete the claim process. This is controlled by .claude/ghe.local.md configuration.
